reviews.review_msg: He doesn't understand deep learning that much and he pretends that he knows it. This is terrible in my opinion. I would like to say buying a course on Udemy or Coursera is better than learning with him. Assignments are not very related to what he is teaching. The quiz is a nightmare, requiring you to read the outdated textbook.

Professor Oliver is very enjoyable to listen to even though the course content is dry and boring. His exams are multiple-choice heavy so if you don't like those then avoid taking this class with him. Otherwise, he is a great 320 teacher.

I really appreciated Dr. Schulte's enthusiasm for the material. He tried to make lectures interesting by showing different types of media. The grading criteria were a little unclear but the assignments were interesting and not that difficult.
Nice, warm, informal, error-prone, academically doubtable, 90% too easy and 10% strikingly difficult material

Dr. Schulte is one of the best lecturers I've had so far at SFU! He made this course very informative and interesting. The assignments were a little bit difficult but Oliver was always happy to help. Exams were not that hard but still required to understand the principles. The only problem was the book because it was SOO boring and overcomplicated!
Oliver is a good choice for those want to learn and enjoy the lecture. The midterm and final might be difficult or easy depends on how did you follow his schedule.
Makes assignments way too easy, so you have an 80 percent average at the end and get a B- because of the curve. Didn't really learn anything useful in this class.

Oliver Schulte is the worst professor I've had at SFU. I had him for CMPT 310 as well as 354 and both courses were unstructured, uninformed gong shows. Everything you learn will be by your own effort; do not rely on this man to teach you anything. Assignments  convoluted. Exams  he allows cheat sheets. Too easy. Curved hard. Material  worthless.

Good lecturer, reasonable pace, and fair assignments + exams. Databases are important and this class was a really good introduction to them. One thing you have to watch out for is that this class is pretty easy, so the average marks are quite high ( low 80's to high 70's) so he scales down the class. Stay on top of everything to get a good mark.
The class average was near 90% ?!!!  He scaled down the class really hard. If you just want to pass this course, take it with him. Otherwise, avoid him.

I understood his lectures, but couldn't really get into them. Sparse, not very useful powerpoints. Had to do some reading in the textbook to really get it. It's overall a pretty easy class. Should have put in more effort, but there was no fear to motivate me. If you have to take 354 with him, don't worry, but try to get someone else if you can.

Just like a comment on 882 below this course was ridiculous. 30% of it he repeated stuff from the machine learning course from an other professor, 70% simply used free resource available online and let students to learn them on their own! Can't even correct mistakes made by students . Had difficulty calculating derivatives of one-variable function.

I don't blame the lack of knowledge on what he teaches but he is dishonest. He DO NOT HAVE CompSci BACKGROUND but always pretends he knows much about it. He wrote on his website that he graduated in computer science from UT but he was actually Cognitive Science majored. In addition, he did his master and Phd in Philosophy Dept at CMU! Not CompSci!

I took his machine learning course. He was using the material from one of the other professors from the department. He did not understand the material himself; therefore the lectures were mostly there to confuse you. I only learned through reading the textbook; watching online courses. To be fair, he tries very hard; he is just not a good teacher!

Awesome prof, nothing but good things. Assignments are extremely long and easy to mess up. If you put in the time, it prepares you for the final + midterm. The problem is time (some can take up to 20 hours).  Very nice and tries really hard for students to learn - SFU could take a hint from him.

He is one of the best teachers I had in this school. In order to convey the meaning of the concepts he teaches, he uses both intuition and technical explanations. He enriches the content of his course with demos and videos, which I found very helpful. He has a talent of making abstract or difficult concepts look simple and easy to understand.

Great Prof!! Highly recommend taking CMPT 354 with him!  His lecture slides are crystal clear, he does an excellent job of explaining concepts, lots of examples, etc.  He had a great marking scheme; if you do better on the final then the midterm (no matter what the marks are), the final will replace the midterm mark!  So impressed!!

This guy is really funny, his actions are just funny. The assignments were long but not too hard. His midterm was okay, but the final.... EKKK yeah not so easy after all.. Overall, the course is interesting.

the whole class was getting B+, and I was getting an A before the final. but i was so disappointed he made the final like 70% harder than other midterms... but good thing is, his lectures are clear, organized with slides, funny, love to let u participate and a good prof. the best of it is you somehow you feel ur learning instead of feeling sleepy.

Great, helpful, funny and accommodating prof! Print out slides and take notes in class, they'll help later. Allows cheat sheets on exams. Assignments are long but you learn a lot and doing them will basically prep your the midterm. Take it with him if you can; I certainly learned a lot + it's easy so far!

A good guy, very willing to help. But if you really want to learn something, you need to do a lot by yourself. His lectures are too straight forward. FYI 31/85 students got more than 90% on MT. assignments are long but not hard. If Database not your concentration go with him you will be fine with your grade. While if not, consider about it.

Good prof who cares. Material wasn't always the most sparkling stuff but he attempts to make lectures interesting. As already mentioned, his assignments are long but really ingrain the material. Grading was fair. Final exam was about right, no surprises.

Great professor, is very willing to help in office hrs. Exams are fair and so are assignments. They're tedious but helpful in learning the material. He allowed cheat sheets for the midterm/final! Really good professor, attend the lectures you'll learn more that way than from the book. Actually cares about his students, its refreshing to see.

His teaching skill is below average,on the other hand, he is pretty laid-back.My biggest complain is that, the fnal is A LOT harder than the midterm,while he said in class the dificulty level should be similar.
He's sloppy and disorganize in his presentations. He cannot answer if anyone has a question. His grading is unfair. To be concise he is awful.

Very determined to teach & has genuine concern for students. He is happy when no one is lagging behind. His lectures were fun & the assignments I did were very practical. If you really want to learn, you can combine the lectures and textbook(naturally).The problem is that students dont like to read. He is one of the best and inspiring profs ever.

Googled some of his lecture notes and found that they were stolen with his name plastered onto them instead. Teaching ability is pretty average, but his assignments are ambiguous and he falls behind the lecture schedule. He obviously doesn't do the assignments first because the second one had an impossible question that later had to be removed.

This got to be a joke of a prof. He always "doesn't want to give too much detail on the assignments' requirements", yet expects you to guess the right solution. Granted the TA for this course is a total failure, but the prof doesn't make the situation any better. Tests are unfair since he likes to test on things that has "no solution". Avoid!
THE WORST PROF EVER

His assignments were exactly  the assignments that Dr. Greg Mori used for his Machine Learning course twice. So almost everyone had already the  correct solutions. Therefore by coping some words and diagrams everybody was happy. Shame for him and his cheating students.

He set 30% (or 40%) for assignments. And there were just two sets of assignments. The questions were absolutely nonsense and funny. He himself even didn't know what his questions meant. He was totally unable to teach.

The most ridiculous course and professor. In the graduate level, at Game Theory, the whole time he was just practicing games like prisoners dilemma, chicken and Rock-paper-scissors, . . . and gave chocolates to the winners or volunteers!! Such a picnic!!

Part of his test is made up of useless details but he allows a cheat sheet for his tests so take notes when reading the book so your cheatsheet will be ready when exam comes along. The midterm is supposed to take 2 hours(or so he says) but everyone finished before 25 minutes.
pretty interesting course.  not much covered, and it's pretty easy too if you know the basics.  the e-commerce stuff was barely tested on the final though...
No Comments
Very nice guy. Tries hard to make the lectures clear and easy to follow. The assignments really help with the exams. The exams covered stuff from the book that wasnt in the lectures - watch out.

He's a sincerely nice guy who will help out tremendously in office hours... However, his tests seem stupid, he seems to test the unimportant things.  That said, his course is pretty easy, just don't expect to learn any of the material in depth.
